sequence: Question: Tell me your full name.
Answer: Elizabeth, with a Z and my middle initial is A and I’1l spell the last name.
Q: Okay.
A: F-e-I-d-h-u-s-e-n. Nobody ever gets it. Feldhusen.
Q: Husen.
A: Feldhusen. I guess in German you’d say Feldhoosen.
Q: Uh-huh.
A: And I say Feldhusen.

Q: Okay... Okay, this is July 14th, 1995, we’re in West Park, New York. This is Nina
Ellis interviewing Elizabeth A. Feldhusen. Tell me please, when -- when were you born
and where were you born?
A: Well, I was born in Brooklyn, New York, April 21st, 1918.
Q: And where were you living when you decided to become a nurse?

A: Oh, I was still living in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, on
MacDonough Street, between Louis Avenue and Stuyvesant, which was a very nice
area at that time. And my family lived there about 10 years and then we moved to Park
Slope in Brooklyn.

Q: And why did you decide you wanted to be a nurse? How did you decide that?
July 14, 1995

A: Well, things happen in my life in peculiar ways. I had been a Girl Scout and when I
was 12 -- I still remember that, we were given a course on home -- I think the Red Cross
gave it -- home nursing and care of the sick. And I just looked at that book and read it
once and the whole thing was memorized. But my mother was always against it, so when
I graduated from high school, I looked for a job, it was in the middle of the Depression
and --
Q: What year did you graduate from high school?

A: In 1936, in June of *36 and I looked for a job and I finally found something in a hair
net factory and I worked one week and I wouldn’t go back. My mother went back for my
seven dollars check or cash -- they paid in cash in those days. And then the same agency
that had gotten me that job, said she would -- I was a Roman Catholic and they kept
asking me if I would change my religion, believe it or not. So by then -- that was around,
I think September, or so. So I finally said, “All right, I'll change it.” So she said, “Just fill
out the card and put Protestant down.” You know, make out the card the same way. And
she sent me over to a place with a -- oh, there must have been about 10 or 12 of us and
they gave us little tests. And the one test I remember was a row of numbers and they said,
just put a circle around, say the seventh. Just go down the whole column and -- and then
we had some other things that were similar and then they disappeared and then they came
out again and they said, “Well, Miss So and So and Miss So and So and Miss Feldhusen
will please remain and the others may go.” So I was hired. And I worked there until -- I
think it was from November, maybe October, until the first of February. And then I went
July 14, 1995
into nurses training. But the way the nurses training came about was that my father tuned
pianos --
Q: Before you tell me this, I want to -- hang on one second.

A: One of his jobs was at Brooklyn State Hospital. In those days they had big state
hospitals.
Q: Okay.

A: So, my father talked to the -- well, when he went to Brooklyn State, he always went
in to see the superintendent and -- and then they would let him know where he was to go.
So he knew the superintendent quite well, so he told him about his daughter, who was
having trouble finding a job. But eventually, you know, I was working. Just doing file
clerk work. And so the superintendent says, “Well, we have a nurses training school here.
Why don’t you have your daughter come and enter our class?” And that was around
October, November. So my father came home and told me that and I said, “Well, I’m
sure the classes started in September and I would be two months later and I’d never be
able to catch up.” So he -- so my father says, “Well, I pass by King’s County Hospital
when I go to Brooklyn State,” cause he went on the subway. And so I wrote to -- to
King’s County and applied and they sent me all the applications and whatnot. Now, they
took classes twice a year and their next class was the first of February. So I was accepted
and -- and then where I was working -- I worked right up until the last day and left and
went into nurses training.

Q: Mm-hm.
July 14, 1995

A: And just by happenstance, I really picked one of the best schools in New York. In it’s
day, it was very, very fine. And I had a friend that went to Bellevue and there was just no
comparison. We were treated like young ladies and we were expected to be young ladies.
And at Bellevue it was helter-skelter, come as you go and just -- really, you had to be
tough to go there. So I -- it worked out very well for me.
Q: And when did you finish your training?

A: Well, that was a three year training course. I mean, they practically don’t have those
any more. But when I graduated -- I had always wanted to go into public health. We had
two months of public health experience as part of our nurses training and I liked it. And
so I went to the Brooklyn Visiting Nurse Association and applied for a position. And she
said, “You have to have one term of college.” So then I went to New York University
and wen -- went to night school. And I finally got my 16 college points and -- and I
worked for them almost a year. But then people were going into the army and I had
patients -- my sickest patients would say to me, “What are you taking care of me for?
You should be taking care of the boys.”
Q: Really?

A: I had that time and time again. So I have a very close friend, and she also wanted to
gO, SO We went in together, and --
Q: When was that?
A: That was very vivid in my mind, the first of July, 1943. I still remember that first day.

Q: What was it like? What happened?
July 14, 1995

A: Oh, it was a day like this, hot as anything and her brother took us to the -- to get the
train to go down to Wilmington, Delaware. And we were given very little instruction as
to what to do. We got down to Delaware -- down to Wilmington and I think some -- it’s
-- there were very brief letter and it said, “You go to Wilmington and you take the army
bus to fort -- to Fort Dupont Delaware.” And we couldn’t find the bus. And there was
no air conditioning in those days and we were rushing around from here to there and we
were there almost all day. And we were so hot. I was exhausted. And we went to the
travelers agency that is supposed to help travelers. They didn’t know a thing about Fort
Dupont. And they were there really to help people in the service. Didn’t know anything
about their bus service. Well finally, as I recall, somebody overheard us. Must have been
a soldier and he said, oh yes, there was a bus around six o’clock at night, something like
that and he told us where to go. So we ended up at Fort Dupont, we didn’t have any
supper and we were just exhausted. And -- and the chief nurse just act as if we were
arriving at eight o’clock in the morning and I thought she was going to put us on duty
right away. But she finally let us go and showed us our rooms and -- and that led -- that
was my first day of army experience and it was really, really -- it wasn’t very pleasant.
Now I was just looking at Phyllis’s photographs. Now she was in big hospitals like
Tilton General and England General and -- and I was very small. We only had seven
nurses and four doctors. Very small place.
Q: There at Fort Dupont?

A: At Fort Dupont, Delaware.
July 14, 1995
Q: Mm-hm.
A: Mm-hm.
Q: How long were you there?

A: I was there I think about a year and a half and then my friend and I were picked to go
overseas and we joined this 131st evacuation hospital and --
Q: Where did you join them?

A: Well, I tried to think. I’m not really -- we went -- I really don’t remember, really, how
we formed, or whether we had to report. Someplace down in South Carolina, that’s
where we left from. But it’s really very vague in my mind.
Q: Were you on the ship then -- on the Queen Elizabeth, crossing with [indecipherable]

A: Yes. We were all together, yes. And I re -- we were -- there were 40 of us and half
were in one state room and half in another state room. And we had bunks up to the
ceiling. And I had a bottom bunk and I really had to lie on the floor in order to get into
that bunk. And then all night long, the ship would go this way and that way, so you’re
either on your feet or on your head. But the reason was -- I don’t know if the other girls
told you, but that we turned every seven minutes in order to avoid the submarines,
because we did not have any escort across the ocean. So --
Q: Were you -- were you nervous?

A: I don’t remember that I was. You know, when you’re young and it was like a -- an
adventure, you know, and all these activities and whatnot you had never been exposed to
July 14, 1995
before. But we were very crowded, that I remember. It was very hard to find a place to sit
down anywheres, you know, they -- we had about 10,000 troops on that ship.
Q: Wow. And 40 nurses.

A: Yeah, well, the nurses, we didn’t do anything. You know, we were just in a group, we
weren’t performing any nursing --
Q: Right, right.
A: Excuse me, any nursing functions.
Q: Were you the only women on the ship?
A: Yeah, as I remember we were the only women.
Q: 40 women out of 10,000.

A: Well, I'll tell you, men were more respectful in those days. In fact, I remember when I
was at Fort Dupont and two of the men -- two of the corpsmen were out in the hall and
one of them used a -- a foul word --
Q: Watch your microphone, now.

A: -- and he immediately came in and apologized. You see, and that wouldn’t exist today,
because the girls themselves use f -- terrible language. I hear it when I go to Brooklyn,
right in the street, so I think women have really damaged themselves by trying to become
-- meet the level of everybody else. So --
Q: Well, tell me what it was like in England. What did you do in England?

A: Well, of course we landed in Greenock, Scotland and we had to climb over the side
and get down into a trawler, because the Queen could only go in so far. And then -- and
July 14, 1995
we tramped, we had these heavy boots on and fatigues and we tramped to a train station
and I can still remember that, the noise, you know, as we walked 1n the street. And
everybody of course, I think everybody was probably nervous because we didn’t know
what was going to happen. And we came to a train station and we got on the train -- and
this is about two or three o’clock in the morning. And we rode for awhile and then we got
off and then we tramped some more and then they said, “The girls will have this building
and then the men will be here and the other men will be there.” And as we went down the
street, everybody got a place to live and you went in and -- and there was a pile of
blankets in the front hall and you grabbed a blanket and you just laid on it and mine was
so greasy. I was awake all night, I couldn’t sleep. And that was the beginning of our
adventure there. And -- see, we were supposed to go right into France and then changes
were made. Something happened to the American troops and so everything was changed.
So then we didn’t do much of anything and finally we were assigned to local units. And I
know I went to Wales and worked there. But I really don’t know how long I was there.
Couple of weeks?
Q: You were care -- you were there caring for [indecipherable]

A: Yeah, we -- they were running ha -- actually American-run hospitals. And the one in
Wales, the nurses lived in -- in these Neesan huts. And when you wanted to take a bath,
you had to run out and well, quite a distance to go to the bathroom or to take your bath.
And -- so you didn’t take a bath too often, but I know the nights when I got off duty, I
had everything all ready and I just grabbed everything and then ran up to that place,
July 14, 1995
because if you didn’t get there first, somebody else did and you didn’t get any more hot
water. So, I mean, even if you took a bath twice a week, at least you -- you got a good
one when you -- if you got there first. So, I was there probably a couple weeks and I was
o -- on a psychiatric ward, which, I never cared for that service, but anyhow -- and then
eventually we were all recalled and then we went over into Europe proper.
Q: All of you 40 together?

A: Yes, all of us, yes. Except one nurse. She was married and before we went overseas,
we had time off and she met her husband in Florida. We were all wondering what’s
happened to her. You know, we lost sight of her. And she got pregnant in that short
period. So by the time we got to England, she knew she was pregnant and they sent her
right home. So we had 39. And we never -- and they told us, if anything happened, we
would never -- nobody would be replaced. So we functioned just with the 39 then.
Q: So you crossed the English channel and --
A: Mm-hm.
Q: -- went to a --

A: Yeah, we did that in the middle of the night also. And they dropped these big gasoline
-- | don’t know what they call them, they’re about as big as gasoline cans. And that went
on all night --
Q: Depth charges.

A: -- you just heard boom, boom, boom, because of the submarines. So, and then we
landed in France. Gee, I’ve forgotten the name of the place. Le Havre --
July 14, 1995
Q: Le Havre.

A: Le Havre is where we -- and I’d never -- course I’d never been to Europe before and
I wanted to see everything I could. And then they loaded us -- loaded us into trucks.
Q: Do you remember what month this would have been?

A: Um, we were not allowed to keep diaries and I had everything with me and we were
told we must get rid of everything. And that’s my -- and a lot of people -- not my -- I
don’t know about my unit, but other people did keep diaries. I mean men. And -- so the
dates are very vague to me. And I don’t know if --
Q: Was it warm, was it summer’? Do you remember?
A: Ob no, no.
Q: Was it -- would have been the --

A: I remember now. Now I’m beginning to remember. When we were still in England,
we landed two days before Christmas. Now it’s coming back to me. And when we were
still back in the States, somebody, one of the girls said, “We’re going to land near
Christmas, let’s get gifts for the men.” And I don’t know who that was, or a couple of
them bought all little gifts and wrapped them all up. And we knew how many people
there were and one of the men dressed up in Santa Claus -- this is after we were in
England and -- and Bowden -- what’s the name? Three names -- anyhow -- and -- and
Santa Claus went around and gave out the gifts and the men were really shook up
because a lot of them are family people. And anyhow, that was our first Christmas. Just
about two days before Christmas was when we landed there.
July 14, 1995
Q: That was Christmas of 1944?
A: Yes.
Q: Right.
A: Yes.
Q: So the Battle of the Bulge was going on?
A: Mm-hm.
Q: In -- on the continent.

A: Which may be why we didn’t go into France directly, mm-hm. And -- but we really --
I mean all these things you hear about, all the -- the Stars and Stripes, that newspaper. I
never saw that paper. We never had any of this entertainment, you know, of the troops
being entertained and -- we never had any of that. We were always very isolated. When
we went into Europe proper, then we were living in tents and there were about six of us
in each squad tent. So we did go over -- I would say February, March, somewheres
around then.
Q: Somebody else told me March.
A: Yeah, it could have been March, mm-hm.
Q: And you were transported then, through France?

A: Well, we always drove in two and a half ton trucks and our unit was always together.
And we had a colonel that was very considerate of the nurses. And he always had a party
go ahead to wherever we were going to be and he had the trenches dug, you know, cause
we -- and the tents put up so when the nurses arrived, they went right into their tents and
July 14, 1995
we had our latrines and everything set up. He always had that done first, he was a very
considerate man. Which is sort of unusual, you know, especially when they’re doctors.
But -- and then he loved to travel and eventually, when we were working at Gusen,
Camp Gusen and we were near some of these -- now one of the girls mentioned this
place and I’ve been there twice. And he knew about it cause he traveled a lot in Europe
and wanted us to see that and I had two chances to go, because not everybody wanted to
gO, SO --

Q: Let’s -- let’s go back a little bit before you got to Gusen. Was that -- that wasn’t the
first place where you set up, you were set up in tents?
A: Oh yeah, we were set up in quite a number of places, yes.
Q: In the spring of ‘45.
A: Mm-hm, yeah.
Q: March, April, May --
A: Mm-hm.
Q: Before the war. There was still fighting going on.

A: Oh yes, April -- I mean, when we were in Germany, when the war was over -- no,
before that, we were going to be overrun by the Germans. We all got a Battle Star for that
and we were given instructions. That I remember vividly and the -- we were told, “Just
continue working as if nothing was happening. Do -- take care of your patients, do the
same thing. And you may be questioned, but just answer the questions, but don’t let it
bother you,” and course we weren’t. But we were very close and you could hear these
July 14, 1995
great, big tanks coming. In fact, one day on my ward, one tank was so close and you
could hear it coming, that even the bed patients got out of bed to see it. You know, you
could hear this noise coming and I guess they were alarmed, because you didn’t know
who it was, but they were Americans. And -- so we were very close, just at that one
period. And that was someplace in Germany. And I couldn’t tell you where.
Q: Mm-hm.

A: And -- and then eventually we went into Austria. And that was when our unit left us
for about a week or two weeks and the colonel said, ““We’ll be back.” And one of the
girls -- she was going with one of the men, that she eventually married. And she started
crying. I can remember Jeannie Albers, so upset. She says, “We’re never going to see
them again.” Anyhow, they did come back when they said they would. And they got us.
And then the colonel, in the morning said, you know, where he had us all standing -- this
makes me very emotional. I can’t help it. Every time I tell this. He said, “You don’t have
to go.” He said, “There’s a lot of tuberculosis and a lot of chronic illnesses and,” he said,
“you don’t have to go if you don’t want to.” Well, everybody went except about three or
four people. And when we came back the next day, everybody went.
Q: Where was -- where were you when he told you this?
A: That was at Gusen.
Q: When you arrived there?

A: Yeah. We were living in Linz. Well, it’s -- we had to go on duty the next day, as soon
as they came and got us.
July 14, 1995
Q: Wait, let -- let me make sure this is clear. You went to Austria from Germany?
A: Yes.
Q: Right.
A: Mm-hm.
Q: And this would have been the end of April, early May?
A: Maybe -- could be.
Q: Now --

A: I’ve always been wanting to get my unit’s -- you know, they ha -- the -- each unit had
to write up their experience and I’ve always been wanting to get a copy of that, because I
don’t know about the dates.
Q: Well, when did he tell you this? Before you got to Linz?

A: Oh no, when we arrived at Linz. He then said he wanted the nurses lined up. You
know, you lined up for everything and -- and we stood and -- and that was when he told
us that -- that we did not have to go if we didn’t want to.
Q: Did he tell you what you would see?

A: I don’t remember. All I remember is that he said, “There’s a great deal of tuberculosis
here,” which is quite infectious, and -- and whatever else he told us, that’s about all I
remember of it. And maybe he told us we’d see a lot of things that -- that we -- you
know, that would be very hard to accept, but I’m very vague on that.

Q: Had you heard anything about concentration camps?
July 14, 1995

A: No, no I never had, no. And now see, some of the girls knew a lot of the officers, you
know, and they may have learned things that way, but I never knew. I never had anything
to do with them, I never bothered. And, well, like that one girl, they were keeping
company, so I’m sure he must have talked to her about things. Now, what he heard, I
don’t know. And so, that’s --
Q: Well, the next day then?

A: Yeah, the next day, we went on duty right away, the next morning. And that was when
he told us that.
Q: And that was at Gusen?
A: Yes, mm-hm.
Q: And what was your responsibility?

A: Well, I had a ward, big ward and there was a great deal of diarrhea and we were
giving out sulfanilamide, which is -- I don’t think it’s a drug used any more, but it’s
before the antibiotics came in. And, oh we gave out like 20 pills and everybody was up in
tiers. In order to get up to the top person, you had to stand on the lower tiers to reach
them. So --
Q: Was this a barracks that they were in?
A: It was like a barracks, yes.

Q: It wasn’t a hospital?
July 14, 1995

A: Well, we ca -- I think our hospital called it the hospital, because all these were the
sickest people. And they were in -- lying in these tiers, these one, two, well at least three -
- three up. So --
Q: Were those the barracks that they had been living in previously?
A: That I really don’t know. That I don’t know.
Q: But you would -- that became your ward then?
A: That was --
Q: You cared for them every day?

A: -- yes, mm-hm, mm-hm. And eventually we got these young German prisoners of war
to help us as ward men. You know, to carry bedpans and urinals and -- and help, and we
had very little to eat. We didn’t have much food and they -- our group went around
thinking they could get food from the German warehouses and they found they were
empty. Everything had been used up, you know, because it was the end, and everybody
was -- I guess the Germans were fleeing and -- and had used up what they could. And
that was really -- I guess they ran out of -- must have ran out of supplies and whatnot. So

Q: And what was the condition of the people when you first saw them? They were all --
were they all men that you were caring for?
A: Yeah. They were all men where I was, yes.

Q: And the first day you saw them, what -- what was their condition? What -- what were
they --
July 14, 1995

A: Well, they were lying in bed and they were weak and very thin. And I guess it was
shocking, you know, when you’re not used to seeing all those types of things and people.
Q: Were they clothed?
A: Yeah, they had shirts on of some kind, mm-hm. And -- and pajamas, seems to me.
Q: The striped? Did they have on the striped --

A: No, I don’t remember that, it just seems to me they had -- they had plain pajamas on. I
don’t really remember exactly what they had on, but they -- they were covered.
Q: Were they able to speak to you?

A: Well, they didn’t speak English, but I can get by with a little German and so that was -
- but I mean there really wasn’t too much to say either, you know, when you’re coming
with the pills and they’re objecting and you’re saying, Si moosta dus taking, you know?
Me with my German and English. So they -- they got the picture and -- and then they’d
swallow them and so --
Q: Were you bathing them or --
A: No, we didn’t do anything like that, no.
Q: Did other people do that for them?

A: No. I don’t think so. Really, it just took you all day giving out the medication. So --
and whether --
Q: Why did that take so long? Why did it take --

A: Well, because we had so many people. Oh, I had a big ward. I don’t know, I had
rooms and rooms with all these people on t -- in tiers, you know, three or four tiers going
July 14, 1995
up. In one room you had, boy, three, four, eight, 12 -- sic -- I bet you had about at least
20 people in one room. You know, all these like three and three. It’s sort of vague to me,
though.
Q: And they -- did you feed them, were they -- did you have food for them?

A: Well, we had food. And that’s another thing. I don’t quite recall how we did that. We
would have to have had trays, unless we had -- maybe there were tin dishes and we gave
them the dishes, you know. That, again, is vague to me. I -- just how we did that. I don’t
remember any more.
Q: What kinds of precautions were you able to take to protect yourself from --
A: We really didn’t take any.
Q: Nothing?
A: No, we had fatigues on and that was all. We didn’t wear gowns or anything.
Q: Other people have mentioned DDT spray.

A: Oh, that’s another thing, yes. Before we went on duty, we had a gun that was about
that long and they’d fill it with DDT and then it had a plunger and you held your thing
out -- your suit open like this and somebody would plunge it and plunge it down the
back. And then your hair was all done -- we wore helmets.
Q: It was powder, DDT powder’?

A: It was powder, yes. And -- and I don’t know, I had cancer of the breast and nobody
ever asked me if I was exposed to DDT. And I often wonder if it had anything to do with
July 14, 1995
that. But then, there are an awful lot of women that have had the same thing that I have.
So -- but we certainly was full of DTT.
Q: Every day?
A: Every day we did it. Tons of it. Nobody realized how dangerous it was.
Q: You were probably grateful to have it?

A: Yeah. Yeah, because they said there might be lice, you know and whatnot and so --
but I never caught anything.
Q: Did anybody”?

A: I don’t think so. I was very sick when I was in England, but that’s before I ever had
any contact with them. So, I think we were all quite healthy.
Q: In the evenings, when you weren’t on duty, what -- what did you do?

A: Well, all we had were these tents to sit in. We went on walks. Oh, that was in
England, when I went on that walk. I don’t -- oh, I know, when we were in Germany, in
one area, a whole group of us, including the men, decided to go on a walk and we did
walk up on a hill. And there was a -- you could hear the cuckoo. You know, in
Germany, the cuckoos sound like the cuckoo clock. Cuckoo, cuckoo. And I -- I was a
birdwatcher and I says, “Oh, I’m dying to see that cuckoo.” So the whole group of us
went up and climbed up that hill and we were walking around and looking and we could
hear it -- cuckoo -- coming from different -- and all of a sudden, bullets started firing.
See, it was a come on. And we got down from there very, very fast. And there was no
mistaking who we were, because we had big Red Crosses on all our tents. Our tents were
July 14, 1995
all down at the base. But you could hear the wi -- the bullets flying right overhead. You
could hear them whistling. Never saw anybody. So --

Q: When you were at -- working every day at Gusen in Austria. D-Do you remember
ever going out into the town there, seeing the local people at all? Did you
[indecipherable]

A: Well we lived -- we lived about 10 miles away and they transported us back and forth
by truck. And we did -- in the building I was -- we were 1n two houses and -- the nurses
were and -- cause we were all bunched up together in the rooms and we had a -- a girl -- a
German girl that took care of -- kept everything clean and whatnot. And -- but we really
didn’t converse very much with her, because most of the girls didn’t know any German
and she didn’t know any English. But there was one girl in my group that wanted a
tablecloth that she had fixed up nicely -- to decor -- you know, make everything look
nicer. And she wanted that tablecloth and she said, you know, “Ask her,” you know, “if I
can have the tablecloth of if she’ ll sell 1t to me or what.” So I asked her. And she said,
“No.” She says, “My husband gave me that and I don’t know where he is.” So -- I mean
the sorrow was on their side also. So war is just awful. That’s why this Bosnia really
bothers me -- what they’re doing there to people. Just awful.
Q: Yeah. When -- how long did you stay there, working at Gusen?

A: Well, we came home -- the war in Japan -- well, while we were still -- no, that was in
Germany, when the war was over and Hitler killed himself and my friend Grace
brought this radio with her. I think she was ready to throw it away many a time. And --
July 14, 1995
you could never really get anything on it, cause we had so little ele-electricity, but she
had it connected that night and we could hear the funeral music. And we said something
has happened. But we found out later, you know, that Hitler had killed himself. And that
was all -- you know, everything was garbled, you couldn’t get anything. We hardly had a
